attributes.action: Ban the sale of artificial grass
attributes.background: It is environmentally irresponsible to allow garden space occupied by grass & other plant life (which processes CO2 & supports wildlife) to be replaced by plastic which does not biodegrade.
attributes.additional_details:
Natural Grass & Plants encourage a healthy ecosystem, capturing CO2.
 
Banning the sale of artificial grass could be a small step towards increasing the UK biodiversity, reducing our carbon footprint & helping our ever dwindling insect & wildlife population. Artificial grass:

1) Creates huge volumes of plastic
2) Can’t always be recycled
3) Can pollute soil with microplastics
4) Has a large carbon footprint
5) Contributes to flooding
6) Can overheat making artificial grass lawns unusable
7) Has NO wildlife benefit

government_response.summary: The Government has no plans to ban the use of artificial grass.
government_response.details:
The relevant legislation and policy measures pertaining to this issue are devolved matters. This response is relevant to England.

The Government’s 25 Year Environment Plan sets out our ambition to eliminate all avoidable plastic waste. We are making great strides to tackle plastic pollution. The Government’s Resources and Waste Strategy for England, published in 2018, outlines the ways in which we will meet this ambition by taking action across each stage of the product lifecycle as we move towards a more circular economy:
www.gov.uk/government/publications/resources-and-waste-strategy-for-england

We know more needs to be done and for the most problematic plastics we are going faster. This is why we have committed to work towards all plastic packaging on the market being recyclable, reusable or compostable by 2025. 

We prefer to help people and companies make the right choice, rather than banning items outright. However, where progress is insufficient, we will explore alternative policy measures, which may involve bans as part of a wider strategic approach. For instance, in 2018, the Government introduced a ban on microbeads in rinse-off personal care products and in October 2020, we introduced restrictions on the supply of plastic straws, stirrers and plastic-stemmed cotton buds. 

Furthermore, we have reduced the use of single-use carrier bags by the main supermarket retailers by 95% with our 5p charge. To build on the success of this charge, we have now increased it to 10p and extended it to all retailers. We will continue to review the latest evidence on problematic products and/ or materials to take a systematic approach to reducing the use of unnecessary single-use plastic products.

It is for local authorities to comply with the legal and policy safeguards in place to protect biodiversity and ensure sustainable drainage. The Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006 (the NERC Act) requires all public authorities in England to have regard for conserving biodiversity in the exercise of their functions. Our most important designated sites and species are also protected under legislation. 

The Government is introducing new requirements to maintain and enhance the natural environment in England. We are mandating biodiversity net gain in our landmark Environment Bill to ensure that new developments enhance habitats for biodiversity. Surfaces such as artificial grass are of no value to wildlife, so any developer or local authority seeking to demonstrate biodiversity net gain would be incentivised to avoid the use of such surfaces in their developments’ shared green spaces. 

In addition, the Environment Bill strengthens the current NERC Act biodiversity duty on public authorities to require them to take action to conserve and enhance biodiversity; and introduces a reporting requirement for those public authorities with the greatest potential to enhance biodiversity. This will further incentivise public authorities to adopt approaches that improve the environment. We will also develop guidance to help local planning authorities identify actions they can take to comply with the strengthened duty.

Therefore, the Government has no plans to ban the use of artificial grass. We prefer to help people and organisations make the right choice rather than legislating on such matters. However, the use of artificial grass must comply with the legal and policy safeguards in place to protect biodiversity and ensure sustainable drainage, while measures such as the strengthened biodiversity duty should serve to encourage public authorities to consider more sustainable alternatives.

Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban single use plastics and the unnecessary use of plastic packaging
attributes.background: The change needs to start in super markets, big brands and companies. They need to be forced to change their packaging to sustainable material. Companies like Galaxy are already using a plant based packaging for their vegan chocolate, it can be done. Our oceans and planet need us to change.
attributes.additional_details: Single use plastics are polluting the world, they need to be banned. Our oceans are being destroyed. We actively ship recycling to other countries whose lands are polluted with our plastic waste. Single use masks are being discarded everywhere and being found in the oceans. Animals and their homes are dying. We are running out of room for anymore plastic wastage. It is in our water, air, fish, land. It needs to stop.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of disposable vapes.
attributes.background: A recent innovation in vape technology, the disposable vape is becoming increasingly popular & is already one of the most frequent items of litter. These single-use plastics are now routinely found lying in the street, concealed amongst vegetation, floating in watercourses & on coastal strandlines.
attributes.additional_details: By outlawing the sale of disposable vapes the UK Government and Parliament can nip in the bud a new and rapidly increasing form of single use plastic pollution.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban single-use plastic bottles in the manufacture of soft drinks for UK market
attributes.background:
We want the Government to take action to cut down plastic pollution by banning single-use plastic bottles in the manufacture of soft drinks in the UK.
We say planet before profits and support us in telling the Government to take action today, ban the use of plastic bottles for soft drinks.
attributes.additional_details:
We are here to shout at the top of our lungs “End the OBSESSION with plastic bottles. Let’s stop choking up our oceans, and clogging our beaches and landfills with this unnecessary type of plastic bottle”

The UK Government must ban the use of harmful plastic bottles in soft drinks.

You ask what does this mean for our favourite soft drinks? It means companies need to take a green approach to their manufacturing process, and put our planet before their shareholders profits!

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund a universal income by taxing environmentally damaging products
attributes.background: Introduces 'sin taxes' (like those on tobacco and alcohol) to environmentally damaging products and services, eg. single use plastics, harmful chemicals, fertilizers and pesticides, meat and dairy, polluting transportation, etc. The money raised is then given back to everyone via a universal income.
attributes.additional_details: Environmentally friendly options are often expensive. If we make the alternatives products pay for the damage they cause, there will be a level playing field.  Prices will rise, but affordability will not be an issue as people will be in receipt of a universal income to compensate. Those who switch to a more environmentally friendly lifestyle and those on low incomes will benefit most, funded by environmentally unfriendly people and those on higher incomes.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban balloon releases which are harmful to wildlife
attributes.background: Balloon releases can be harmful to wildlife and can cause plastic waste pollution. Seals and birds get tangled up in the plastic waste left behind. It is illegal to drop litter in the streets and it should be illegal to release balloons into the air.
attributes.additional_details:
Plant a tree or erect a bench, but please stop these balloon releases
Prevention of even more plastic pollutants

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce a levy on single-use disposable plastic
attributes.background:
I want the UK Government and Parliament to introduce a levy on single-use disposable plastic manufactured and sold in the UK.

This will help consumers, business and industry transition towards more sustainable solutions; ones that are long term and ones that consider the entire product lifecycle.
attributes.additional_details:
The impact of plastic pollution on our natural environment isn’t just a problem for the UK. It’s a global one. 

In 2021 the UK will host COP26 and the G7. Whilst SARS-CoV-2 (COVID19) will dominate the conversation, the UK must use these events to tackle plastic pollution as well as climate change and the effect it will have on our natural environment. 

This levy may create a fund for research into the effects of plastic pollution as well as solutions that may lead to an outright ban.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Include the impact of fast fashion on the curriculum
attributes.background: Change the curriculum to include the environmental impact of fast fashion. In  lessons children should be taught the importance of repairing instead of re-buying and be educated on the air miles, water consumption and human suffering put into fast fashion.
attributes.additional_details: The Conservative Manifesto promises they will "crack down on the waste and carelessness that destroys our environment" as well as tackles plastic pollution "both in the UK and internationally." Currently the fashion industry accounts for around 20% of wastewater and 10% of Co2 emissions. Change starts with education, therefore in order to live up to these promises, changes to the curriculum must be made.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban selling drinks bottles that aren’t made out of a sustainable material.
attributes.background: Create a ban for all drinks bottles or containers that aren’t made from a sustainable, biodegradable, compostable, 100% recycled or recyclable materials. This could include packaging it in recyclable cans, rice husk, recyclable cartons, coconut wood etc. Single use plastics must be avoided.
attributes.additional_details: There is a massive global issue regarding single use plastic and plastic pollution, and a large proportion of this waste is produced by plastic bottles and drinks. The aim is to steer people away from continuously buying plastic bottles, especially for water, and instead to buy drinks packaged in materials that can be absorbed back into the earth. This would be a huge step towards making our country green and environmentally conscious, which is so important at this time.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require companies to annually publish plastic usage (product and packaging)
attributes.background: Just as companies must publish financial audits, an audit of the amount and types of plastic it uses for creation of product and packaging/every day use is of vital public interest and should be made to be published in detail so we consumers can make informed choices on where our money is going.
attributes.additional_details: The problem of plastic pollution is well documented, it harms a multitude of animal species and has even entered the food chain. Companies make choices on what materials they choose to produce with and package with. As consumers we demand transparency and auditing by law on the amount and types of plastic (e.g. recyclable and non recyclable) being generated by each business in all aspects to be made public each year.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ensure all UK's plastic waste  is processed and recycled in the UK
attributes.background: Prevent the export of plastic waste produced in the UK from being exported to other countries to deal. We are environmentally obliged to deal with our own waste products and not saddle other countries with the burden.
attributes.additional_details:
We are the second largest producers of plastic waste after the USA (BBC 15/05/21). The waste is being exported to countries who unscrupulously and illegally dispose of the UK's plastic waste by dumping it in the countryside or burning it in the open causing pollution, beyond the controls of the UK once it has left our shores.
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-57139474

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Set stricter legal targets for air quality and increase funding for research
attributes.background: The Government’s planned new legal targets for air quality must align with the WHO air quality guideline levels. It should also increase funding for research and development to develop cleaner energy sources and reduce plastic air pollution from tyres. This will also help combat climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Each year at least 28,000 people in the UK die prematurely because of air pollution, including children. Air pollution has been linked to heart disease, lung disease and cancer, and can exacerbate allergies, skin conditions and pregnancy complications. 
 
Currently we are above the World Health Organisation guideline levels for multiple pollutants. Data from the World Bank shows that 66% of the UK population were exposed to pollution above the WHO standards in 2017.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of super trawlers in UK waters
attributes.background: We are interested in the banning of super trawlers to take a step in the right direction to heal one of our most important ecosystems. We hope this will help regulate overfishing in UK waters, and reduce the amount of fishing related plastic waste in the British Isles.
attributes.additional_details: The ocean is currently being grossly overfished, destroying many vital ecosystems which are necessary for all human life. Banning the use of super trawlers would take a very important step to healing the ocean floor, would greatly reduce fishing related plastic waste that pollutes our own waters and the ocean as a whole, and finally, would also contribute to the prevention of the accidental fishing of dolphins, sharks, and whales off of our coastline.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Deposit scheme on  glass, plastic, steel, aluminium bottles and cans.
attributes.background: The UK government to launch a consultation on a deposit scheme that could see a refundable charge added to the cost of single-use glass, plastic, steel and aluminium bottles and cans sold in the UK in an effort to combat pollution, reduce waste and increase recycling.
attributes.additional_details: I would like to see the UK Government instigate a deposit scheme on all single-use glass, plastic, steel and aluminium bottles and cans that are sold singly or part of a multi pack in the UK. The scheme should fund a local repository and collection service that ensures the Items are recycled rather than littered across the UK Countryside, Towns and Cities. The scheme should also support research into the manufacture of biodegradable single-use glass, plastic, steel and aluminium bottles and cans. The education of the British public to engage in local conservation actions to collect, remove  and recycle these products within their local areas. I think the majority of the UK would relish the opportunity to banish the said waste products before the environmental effects  become irreversible.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of plastic bottles
attributes.background: We want the Government to take action to cut down plastic pollution by banning the manufacture and sale of plastic bottles, which make up a significant proportion of all plastic packaging.
attributes.additional_details: In order to tackle this problem a ban is required.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of dog waste bags not made of plant-based material
attributes.background: Ban the manufacture and sale of plastic (including degradable) dog waste bags to reduce use of petroleum and to cut CO2 emissions and plastic pollution.
attributes.additional_details:
Millions of dog waste bags are thrown away every day. Some into trees!

The vast majority are made of plastic, and are not recyclable by their use. Even degradable plastic uses petroleum products and degrades to form CO2. 

There's a clear strategy by the vendors of the degradable bags to make them seem environmentally friendly as people don't appreciate they help cause global warming. 

Plant-based bags (e.g. corn starch) are sustainable and non-polluting. We already use them as food waste bags.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban non-compostable multi-layer material food packaging by 2030
attributes.background: The Government must ban non-compostable mixed material consumer food packaging by 2030. This should force manufacturers to use compostable packaging such as PLA instead for multi-layer material packaging e.g. crisp packets.
attributes.additional_details: The UK can set the example, leading change in the global market using our consumer power. Producers must adapt to a changing world, and shift to working under a circular economy. This legislation can begin this change. Although supplementary, we must look past recycling to instead reduce the use of plastic, reverse waste pollution and the growing damage of micro plastics. Our consumption can be reformed and this ambition to reduce our plastic production be realised with this call for change.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban plastic fishing nets in UK waters.
attributes.background: Plastic fishing gear discarded from vessels are polluting our seas and strangling wildlife. A truly biodegradable alternative needs to be rediscovered. Our oceans are a dumping ground for plastic and other rubbish; plastic fishing nets, ropes and other gear form a significant part of that pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Get plastic out of the sea, and stop any more unnecessary plastic waste including nets going into the seas. Persuade the fishing industry that fishing cannot be sustained with so much plastic waste in our oceans, including continued discarding of nets straggling and killing sea creatures.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban fast food companies from using disposable packaging for advertising
attributes.background: Companies should not be allowed to use disposable single use takeaway containers for advertising their brand.  All takeaway food and drink containers must instead only display information regarding the correct disposal of the used packaging and providing this information should be mandatory.
attributes.additional_details: Takeaway food packaging is huge problem for the planet, causing litter and plastic pollution on both land and sea. Currently companies do not discourage the use of this single use packaging as it provides a far reaching opportunity for widespread community advertising both when the packaging is in use and when it is littered. Once packaging doesn't work for them, then companies will look to cut costs by encouraging refillable and reusable packaging solutions instead.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of virgin plastics in all packaging sold in the UK before 2023
attributes.background: Parliament should pass legislation banning the use of virgin plastics (plastics made directly from petrochemicals rather than recycled plastic) in all product packaging sold in the UK by the end of 2022.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK produces more plastic waste than almost all other countries worldwide. Current schemes for plastic recycling do not work, with most UK waste sent overseas, where it is burnt or dumped in the seas, destroying human, plant and animal habitats. 

By banning virgin plastics, manufacturers will be forced to use recycled materials, creating a circular economy that increases the value of recycled plastic that in turn should ensure proper recycling, and reduced pollution and petrochemical use.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the use of non recyclable plastics in food/drink packaging
attributes.background:
I would like to ban the use of non recyclable plastics in food/drink packaging. These plastics can take hundreds of years to biodegrade.

 By using recyclable plastics. we can take another step to eradicate single use plastics altogether.
attributes.additional_details:
Plastic is widely known to be harmful to the environment.
It can take thousands of years to biodegrade. Pollute our oceans harming marine life.
By helping to eradicate single use plastic today. You can help make a better tomorrow

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Extend the ban on plastic microbeads and other microplastics
attributes.background: To reduce plastic pollution and encourage businesses to produce greener products I would like the Government to extend the ban on the use of plastic microbeads to include leave-on cosmetic products, and also ban the use of microplastic emulsifiers.
attributes.additional_details: Extending the current ban on the amount of microplastics used in our products should have many benefits: It should reduce the amount of virgin plastic being produced, reduce plastic pollution in our oceans and other ecosystems, reduce the adverse health effects microplastics can have on humans and animals, and incentivise research into plastic free/ bioplastic alternatives. Reducing dependence on plastics and protecting marine ecosystems could also help the UK reach its net zero carbon targets.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Impose a corporation tax surcharge on companies that produce single-use plastics
attributes.background: Impose a corporation tax surcharge on companies that produce single-use plastics, based on the cost of removing plastic waste from the environment. The worst offenders would pay the highest surcharges, which would act as an incentive to change their behaviour.
attributes.additional_details: Every year billions of single-use plastic bottles and plastic packaging are bought across the UK, most ending up in landfill sites and in the oceans, causing damage to wildlife and resulting in microplastics that pollute the food chain. It can take upwards of 450 years for a single plastic bottle to degrade and so the problem is one that is going to affect future generations. It’s about time the Government took this problem seriously and showed they are serious about sustainability.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban plastic bags illegal and require the use of biodegradable bags instead
attributes.background:
We must pay 5p per general-sized bag. From 1 April this goes up to 10p per bag. Our modern lifestyle means many people are 'impromptu shoppers', and usually have no issue spending 5p. 
Italy introduced biodegradable 'plastic' bags in 2011 and charge less than 5p per bag. Plastic pollutes our planet
attributes.additional_details:
Biodegradable 'plastic' bags have been in use in Italy since 2011 with great success, they don't pollute the environment, which I think as a responsible citizen of this planet we should all be striving to improve on.

I hope that you will all give this serious consideration.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Impose a levy on all plastic production in the UK
attributes.background: I want the Government to impose a levy on plastic production to cover the cost of tidying our land and sea of the unsightliness and dangers of plastic pollution. Our bodies, wildlife, waterways, towns and countryside are awash with non-recyclable, non-biodegradable plastic and plastic particles.
attributes.additional_details: Evidence shows that plastics are not easily reusable or recyclable or biodegradable. A levy is needed to pay for the damage and mess of plastic pollution and incentivise producers to move to more sustainable practices. The amount imposed needs to be enough to mount a demonstrably effective and ongoing clean-up operation, and act as a financial disincentive to continued production.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the advertisement of plastic and non-recyclable toys to children
attributes.background: Regulate which kinds of products can be advertised directly to children (e.g. during kids TV Ad Breaks) to ensure that items made from plastic and non-recyclable materials are not advertised to children.
attributes.additional_details: Plastics are a major part of climate crisis. They can take thousands of years to break down, polluting our environment especially our oceans. When we are actively trying to move towards a greener & more sustainable society it makes no sense to continue heavily promoting plastic toys to our children. If these ads were banned there would be an incentive for this industry to use more sustainable alternatives to produce their products & packaging, the next generation should be encouraged away from plastic.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban cigarettes - The Largest Ocean Polluter
attributes.background: In April 2021 England will officially ban the single use plastics such as straws and cotton buds. Wales will also do the same in Spring 2021. However the largest source of single use plastic pollution is cigarettes. Therefore it would be appropriate to also ban cigarettes.
attributes.additional_details: The Government have agreed to ban single use plastic in 2021, however the list of items banned crucially misses out cigarettes. Cigarettes are the top single use plastic polluter in the world! On top of the plastic and microplastics issue, cigarettes also add harmful chemicals such as nicotine, lead and arsenic into the environment. These chemicals enter our food chain leading to bioaccumulation. They have also been shown to inhibit plant growth on land and reduce crop yeilds.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Reform legislation that allows plastics to go undeclared on textile labels
attributes.background: The Government should require the full disclosure of all fossil fuel derived plastics in textiles and clothing.
attributes.additional_details:
The Textile Products Regulations allows some parts, which often contain fossil fuel derived materials, to not be listed on composition labels in clothing and textile products.
 
Plastic production from fossil fuels for synthetic fibres is increasing. Fossil fuel extraction is the primary cause of our climate crisis. Recycling is not a solution.
 
We believe incomplete labelling of textile products is a silent contributor to the catastrophe of global warming and plastic and microplastic pollution that’s devastating our ecosystems. Obscuring the full facts denies UK citizens the choice of reducing their plastic footprint.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Charge companies for improper disposal of products and fly-tipping
attributes.background: 8 million tons of plastic end up in the ocean every year because of improperly disposed products and 11% of all methane in the atmosphere already comes from trash. The law fines people for improper recycling, for fly-tipping, etc, but does not fine companies.
attributes.additional_details:
People cannot bear the full burden of improperly disposed products. 

In USA, companies were being sued by a California environmental group for ‘creating a plastic pollution ‘nuisance’ and misleading consumers about the recyclability of plastic.

It is time the UK to lead the charge against improperly disposed products by ALSO charging companies for their improperly disposed products

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Allow the sale of nicotine e-liquids in bottles greater than 10 ml.
attributes.background: I would like the government to change the law or regulation that prohibits the sale of nicotine-containing e-liquid in bottles greater than 10ml due to the negative environmental impact this has.
attributes.additional_details: As a society, it is important that we reduce our single-use plastic waste. 5.5% of Britons over the age of 18 vape which means that millions of people are buying e-liquids sold in only 10ml bottles. We would save a lot of plastic waste by allowing people to purchase nicotine-containing e-liquids in bottles greater than 10ml (say 100ml) as this would result in a lower plastic to volume ratio which would result in less plastic waste damaging our environment and polluting our oceans.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban plastics in schools
attributes.background: Make a law requiring all schools to stop using plastics and replace them with alternatives.
attributes.additional_details: The current situations regarding pollution from plastics are completely shocking and it should be targeted at schools as they can be one of the biggest plastic polluters in today's society.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban single-use plastics in the UK, akin to laws passed in other countries.
attributes.background: At a time when global warming and massive pollution are becoming more pressing issues, more needs to change. A ban on the sale of single use plastics, such as utensils, straws, cup lids, single use plastic bottles and more, could have a big impact on this.
attributes.additional_details: 4.8-12.7 million tonnes of plastic enter the ocean each year https://www.nhm.ac.uk/discover/quick-questions/how-much-plastic-is-in-the-ocean.html

rejection.details:
We currently have the following petition open which you might like to sign:

Ban All Single Use Plastics and Plastic Packaging to Save Our Planet
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/607466

attributes.action: Turn a third of UK coastal seas into fully protected areas for fish population.
attributes.background:
David Attenborough in One Planet, Coastal Seas (Netflix Series) said: 

“We have far too few marine sanctuaries. We need to turn a third of all our coastal seas into properly protected areas, if we do that, our fishing grounds would recover and help sustain both humanity and the natural world.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK currently has 24% of coastal areas under some form of protection but commercial fishing is sometimes still allowed in these areas. We need to beef that up to 33% and make them fully protected. 

Also recent seaspiracy on Netflix brings to light plastic pollution is over 50‰ down to fishing vessels leaving plastic nets in the ocean which kill far more animals than straws and they make lots of money from this.

https://www.wwf.org.uk/what-we-do/projects/protecting-uk-seas 

So let's do it!

rejection.details:
Ban fishing on a third of UK coastal for fish repopulation
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/553334

attributes.action: Reduce The Amount Of Plastic Pollution In Essex
attributes.background: In Essex I have noticed that there is a lot of litter around where I live, specifically plastic bottles and single-use plastics. Having a bigger litter picking team or more bins placed in different towns can help a lot in saving the look and status of our county, and helping Earth.
attributes.additional_details: plastic pollution is a big problem because it harms/kills seabirds and marine life, like the fish we eat and it is growing to more and more of a problem, because more and more people are complaining about the plastics they find in their food. Plastics that float into the ocean are being accumulated together by ocean currents. Starting this change in a county like ours may boost other county's into doing the same and saving our world one plastic at a time.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is the responsibility of your local council.
	
You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

You can petition Essex County Council directly here: https://www.essex.gov.uk/get-involved/petitions

We have published a number of related petitions, which you might like to sign:

Establish a national waste plastic collection/recycling programme for England: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/553651

Implement a Deposit Return Scheme for glass and plastic in 2021: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550260

attributes.action: Introduce biodegradable cigarette filter tips for sale in all uk supermarkets
attributes.background: Plastic filter tips are one of the largest contributors to litter and pollution on land and in the oceans. They take decades to break down, therefore once in the environment they cause issues for many years. This is why the government must ensure the provision of more eco-friendly alternatives.
attributes.additional_details: Cigarette filter tips are ubiquitous both in urban and coastal environments, they are the most common form of litter found during beach clean ups, with about 4 TRILLION being discarded into the environment globally each year. Once in the environment these filters cause harm such as degrading habitats through the leaching of harmful toxins or the deaths of organisms through ingestion. therefore it is important there is greater accessibility to biodegradable alternatives.

rejection.details:
Deciding whether to stock biodegradable filter tips is a matter for individual retailers, not the Government or House of Commons.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Ban plastic cigarette filters: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/330424

Require products containing plastic to be clearly labelled: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550136

attributes.action: I would like you to stop exporting plastic waste from the UK to poorer countries
attributes.background: The UK currently is the second largest exporter of plastic to poorer countries. The EU have banned export of plastic from 1 January 2021, however we have not. The plastic that we export often ends up in the ocean polluting the ecosystems of our planet, or it is burnt or ends up as land fill waste.
attributes.additional_details: We need to be leading the way on environmental issues such as this. It is not okay for the UK to be exporting plastic. We should be actively looking into sustainable alternatives to plastic use in the UK and also stepping up our own recycling abilities. It is also not okay that we are asking poorer countries to take our waste, for then it to pollute the environment in so many harmful ways. This is a global concern, that we have the utmost responsibility for.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/331061

attributes.action: Ban single-use plastic bottles of water
attributes.background: Ban all plastic bottled water. We can easily use tap water and save the environment. If needed, we could add water dispensers in shops so you can fill up your own bottle. Some towns and cities have already banned plastic water bottles so it is not that difficult!
attributes.additional_details: It will help climate change because the factories that make the bottles  will not be producing as much carbon dioxide and it will help plastic pollution a lot because there will not be as many plastic bottles in the seas and in our environment.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/552450.

attributes.action: Compostable packaging must be used all for fresh food and takeaway containers
attributes.background: Manufacturers of all goods that have a short shelf life, such as readymade sandwiches and snacks, must package their goods using only materials that will degrade or compost quickly. These materials, such as starch-based plastic alternatives, are effective, hygienic and readily available.
attributes.additional_details:
Currently, items which can only sit on the shelves for 48hrs are packaged in materials which last for hundreds of years.

Despite decades of anti-litter campaigns, our countryside is still strewn with plastic litter every day, damaging our wildlife and waterways.

This simple change would help reduce the masses of needless non-recyclable waste being generated and reduce plastic litter pollution. With effective alternative materials readily available, now is the time to enforce their use.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a very similar action:

'Ban packaging that is not biodegradable or domestically recyclable': https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/574939

You might also like to sign this petition which calls for a relation action: 

'Make it illegal to manufacture or sell products using non-recyclable plastic':
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/561894

attributes.action: Ban All Single-Use Plastic Bags in the UK
attributes.background: It’s estimated that by the year 2050 there will be more plastic in the oceans than fish. Most single use plastic bags are non-recyclable and will end up in our environment as well as our oceans, polluting and ruining the ocean’s ecosystems. We want the Government to ban all single use plastic bags.
attributes.additional_details:
By banning the single use plastic bag, the UK can send a powerful message that it can be a global environmental leader and inspire other countries to follow our lead. Retailers should offer recycled paper bags for 10p fee or offer reusable bags made out of sustainable materials such as hemp, linen, bamboo, etc. 

Please sign the petition and once you are done share it with everyone you know who cares about the environment and their future on this planet.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

Ban plastic bags in supermarkets, and other retail shops: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/328310

Ban plastic bags for online supermarket deliveries: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549991

attributes.action: Require drive-thru takeaways to write customer vehicle reg numbers on packaging.
attributes.background: Litter from fast food and coffee drive-thru takeaways is blighting our urban and rural landscapes. Voluntary measures have failed. An effective solution would be to require businesses to write customer vehicle registration numbers on packaging, forcing people to dispose of their rubbish responsibly.
attributes.additional_details: During the coronavirus lockdown, litter from fast food outlets all but disappeared. But with the easing of restrictions, discarded fast food packaging has begun to increase on roadsides and at beauty spots, causing plastic pollution and draining the public purse. Councils and Highways England spend nearly £700m a year cleaning up litter. The Government could reduce this cost by introducing a requirement for vehicle registrations to be recorded on all drive-thru takeaway packaging.

attributes.action: Ban single-use plastic bottles in the manufacture of soft drinks for UK market
attributes.background:
We want the Government to take action to cut down plastic pollution by banning single-use plastic bottles in the manufacture of soft drinks in the UK. 
We say planet before profits and support us in telling the Government to take action today, ban the use of plastic bottles for soft drinks.
attributes.additional_details:
We are here to shout at the top of our lungs “End the OBSESSION with plastic bottles. Let’s stop choking up our oceans, and clogging our beaches and landfills with this unnecessary type of plastic bottle”

The UK Government must ban the use of harmful plastic bottles in soft drinks. 

You ask what does this mean for our favourite soft drinks? It means companies need to take a green approach to their manufacturing process, and put our planet before their shareholders profits!

attributes.action: Remove single use plastic bags from supermarkets
attributes.background: The current cost of single use plastic bags in supermarkets is too low to deter the majority of customers from purchasing them. Remove the the option of purchasing single use plastic bags for 10p. Instead only sell multi-use bag options such as 'bags for life' for a minimum of £1.
attributes.additional_details: The current volumes of plastic waste in our oceans and environment is shocking and is only increasing. Single use plastic bags from supermarkets directly contribute to plastic pollution which could be easily avoided. We need to act now before it's too late. By only having the higher price £1 multi-use bag options, customers will be more likely to remember to bring a bag instead of purchasing new ones each time.

attributes.action: Give food companies a year to reduce their plastic packaging by at least 50%.
attributes.background:
Put pressure on food companies especially those who sell to supermarkets to reduce their plastic packaging.
Single use plastic is damaging the environment and wildlife. Alternatives like paper can be easily used.
attributes.additional_details: At the moment citizens are responsible for being the “demand” for products meaning we’re being blamed for choosing products with high plastic content. However there is not much of a choice when everything you find in the supermarket is covered in single use plastic polluting the world.

rejection.details:
Petitions needs to call on the Government or House of Commons to take a specific action. We understand that you're concerned about the impact of food packaging, but it's not clear what you want the Government to do about this.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Ban selling drinks bottles that aren’t made out of a sustainable material: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/311520

Ban plastic wrapping of individual items of fruit or vegetables: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/551544

Increase VAT tax on products that utilize or contain plastic: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550925

If you would like the Government to take an action not covered by the above petitions, you could start a new petition requesting this, but it would need to be clear what action you want the Government to take.

attributes.action: Replace usage of plastic bags for loose foods in supermarkets with paper ones.
attributes.background: To replace the usage of plastic bags with paper bags will help many shoppers become encourage to live a more sustainable lifestyle, due to being a simple step in reducing plastic waste and pollution. Many people are encourage to buy foods in plastic packaging - this could be a simple fix.

attributes.action: Reduce plastic food packaging to save lives from Covid-19 and create less waste.
attributes.background: To put laws in place to immediately reduce any unnecessary packaging, particularly in supermarkets.
attributes.additional_details:
Covid-19 is thought to be spread on food packaging particularly plastics and metal where it can live for up to 3 days. By reducing  packaging it could slow down the spread of the virus and mean that vulnerable people feel less anxious.
We have all seen that plastic is polluting our seas, killing fish, turtles and other sea creatures. It also uses large amounts of carbon to create plastic and metal packaging which is often single use.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300152

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You can read NHS tips to help if you are worried about coronavirus here: https://www.nhs.uk/oneyou/every-mind-matters/coronavirus-covid-19-anxiety-tips

You can read impartial analysis of the Government response to coronavirus and policy developments here: https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/coronavirus/

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
 
Find out more and watch the Committee put questions suggested by petitioners to Government Ministers and the Deputy Chief Medical Officer: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/news/145767/committee-question-deputy-chief-medical-officer-and-ministers-on-coronavirus-response/
 
Read letters asking further questions of Government Ministers: https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/326/petitions-committee/publications/3/correspondence/

attributes.action: Ban the use of all single-use plastics; such as cups, packaging, and bags.
attributes.background: Instil a firm ban on all single-use plastics and polystyrene. The UK is a first-world country and has the resources to become more environmentally friendly as a society, this ban is the first step.
attributes.additional_details: The world is in the midst of an escalating climate crisis. The continuous supply of non-recyclable, single-use items, such as plastic cups at a water fountain or plastic bags used to carry groceries, damages the atmosphere from manufacturing emissions, fills space in landfills, and kills animals from pollution on both land and in the sea. Instilling this ban will not only raise awareness about the global climate crisis but it will also lead a strong trajectory to a more eco-friendly Britain.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petition:

Ban All Single Use Plastics and Plastic Packaging to Save Our Planet
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/607466

attributes.action: Introduce that at least 25% of all clothes in the UK are made from British wool.
attributes.background: Ensure that wool from British farms is used to create domestically produced clothing. This would help reduce pollution from plastics which is e.g. linked to micro fibres from synthetic fleece garments. It would also mean that clothing is biodegradable and more environmentally friendly overall.
attributes.additional_details: Using wool produced in the UK would help develop the textile industry. Develop a new high quality textile industry would also provide jobs and opportunities for skilled workers. It would raise the price wool which of an undervalued commodity. Help create longer lasting clothing which will reduce waste. Provide sheep farmers with an income that does not rely on subsidies.

rejection.details:
Decisions on which materials are used in the manufacturing of clothes are a matter for manufacturers and retailers, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could have a petition calling on the Government to ban the sale of clothes containing wool sourced from outside the UK, if that is something you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Make multi-layer material consumer food packaging compostable by 2030 in the UK
attributes.background: Parliament must vote to make mixed material consumer food packaging in the UK compostable and a legal requirement by 2030. Multi-layer material packaging e.g. crisp packets must use compostable or single material packaging. Goods that do not meet these regulations by 2030 will be taxed.
attributes.additional_details: The UK can set the example, leading change in the global market using our consumer power. Producers must adapt to a changing world, and shift to working under a circular economy. This legislation can begin this change. Although supplementary, we must look past recycling to instead reduce the use of plastic, reverse waste pollution and the growing damage of micro plastics. Our consumption can be reformed and this ambition to reduce our plastic production can be realised with this call for change.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see new requirements for certain types of food packaging, but it's not clear if you want all such packaging to be recyclable, or made of a single material, or something else.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Put water fountains in public to reduce people buying single-use plastic bottles
attributes.background: Putting water fountains in public spaces will mean that people buy less single use plastic bottles. Plastic is destroying our Earth, clogging our oceans and killing our wildlife. Water fountains will let you refill your bottle without polluting the oceans.
attributes.additional_details: Plastic pollution is becoming a big problem (by 2050 there will be more plastic than fish in the oceans). Water fountains in public are common in other European countries - so why aren’t they here? It is a free way for people to save the environment. Placing just one water fountain in a public space could save our Earth and stop polluting our seas. There isn’t a Planet B so we need to do all we can to stop this plastic problem.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334268

attributes.action: Ban plastic bags
attributes.background: In April 2020 the government had promised to ban plastic bags. Due to coronavirus this got delayed and then cancelled. Now the government is saying in April 2021 they will increase the charge on plastic bags to 10p saying that the 'war on plastic' has been 'stepped up'. This is not good enough.
attributes.additional_details: Currently 8 million pieces of plastic pollution find their way into our oceans everyday. This kills one marine mammal or sea bird every 30 seconds. If countries like Rwanda and Kenya can ban disposable plastic bags, then the UK can. We can do better than just charging 10p, we can ban plastic bags completely. This was set to happen anyway in April 2020 and it has not. There is no excuse. The UK government needs to keep to its promises and do more to tackle this pandemic of plastic pollution.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/328310
